s0001: The ancestors of Qin were descendants of Emperor Zhuanxu, and a descendant named Nüxiu.
s0002: While Nüxiu was weaving, a dark bird dropped an egg, which Nüxiu swallowed and gave birth to a son named Daye.
s0003: Daye married a daughter of Shaodian, named Nühua.
s0004: Nühua gave birth to Dafei, who helped Yu control the floods.
s0005: When the work was complete, the Emperor bestowed a dark jade tablet.
s0006: Yu received it and said: 'It was not I alone who accomplished this; Dafei assisted me.'
s0007: Emperor Shun said: 'Ah, you Fei, you assisted Yu's work, and I bestow upon you a black pennant.
s0009: He then gave him a beautiful woman of the Yao surname as wife.
s0010: Dafei bowed and accepted, and assisted Shun in taming birds and beasts. Many birds and beasts became tame, and he was called Boyi.
s0011: Shun bestowed upon him the surname Ying.
s0012: Dafei had two sons: the first was Dalian, who founded the Niaoshu clan;
s0013: the second was Ruomu, who founded the Fei clan.
s0014: His great-great-grandson was Feichang, whose descendants lived either in the Central States or among the barbarians.
s0015: Feichang, during the reign of Jie of Xia, left Xia and joined Shang, becoming Tang's charioteer and defeating Jie at Mingtiao.
s0016: Dalian's great-great-grandson was named Mengxi and Zhongyan, who had bird-like bodies but spoke like humans.
s0017: Emperor Taiwu heard of this and divined whether to employ him as a charioteer. The divination was auspicious, so he made him a charioteer and gave him a wife.
s0018: From Taiwu onward, the descendants of Zhongyan continued to achieve merit, assisting the Yin state, so the Ying surname became prominent and they became feudal lords.
s0019: His great-great-grandson was Zhongjue, who lived among the Western Rong and protected the western frontier.
s0022: Elai was strong, and Feilian was a swift runner; father and son both served Yin Zhou with their abilities.
s0023: When King Wu of Zhou attacked Zhou, he also killed Elai.
s0024: At that time, Feilian was seeking stone for Zhou in the north. When he returned, having nowhere to report, he built an altar at Mount Huotai to make his report, and found a stone coffin with an inscription reading: 'The Emperor commands Chufu not to participate in Yin's chaos, and bestows upon you this stone coffin to honor the Hua clan.'
s0025: When he died, he was buried at Mount Huotai.
s0026: Feilian had another son named Jisheng.
s0028: Mengzeng was favored by King Cheng of Zhou, and was called 'Dwelling at Gaolang.'
s0029: Gaolang fathered Hengfu, and Hengfu fathered Zaofu.
s0030: Zaofu was favored by King Mu of Zhou for his excellent charioteering, and obtained the four horses Ji, Wenli, Hualiu, and Lu'er. They went on a western inspection tour, enjoying themselves so much they forgot to return.
s0031: When Xu Yanwang rebelled, Zaofu served as King Mu's charioteer, driving swiftly back to Zhou, covering a thousand li in one day to suppress the rebellion.
s0032: King Mu enfeoffed Zaofu with the city of Zhao, and Zaofu's clan thereafter took the surname Zhao.
s0033: From Feilian's son Jisheng down five generations to Zaofu, they separately resided in Zhao.
s0035: Elai Ge, son of Feilian, died young.
s0036: He had a son named Nüfang.
s0037: Nüfang fathered Panggao, Panggao fathered Taiji, Taiji fathered Daluo, and Daluo fathered Feizi.
s0038: Because of Zaofu's favor, they all received the city of Zhao and took the surname Zhao.
s0039: Feizi lived at Quanqiu, where he loved horses and livestock and was skilled at raising them.
s0040: The people of Quanqiu reported this to King Xiao of Zhou, who summoned him to manage horses between the Qian and Wei rivers, and the horses multiplied greatly.
s0041: King Xiao wished to make him the legitimate heir of Daluo.
s0042: The daughter of the Marquis of Shen was Daluo's wife, and she bore a son Cheng as the legitimate heir.
s0043: The Marquis of Shen then said to King Xiao: 'Formerly, my ancestress, a woman of Mount Li, was wife to Rong Xuxuan and bore Zhongjue. Because of this kinship, they returned to Zhou and protected the western frontier, and the western frontier was peaceful because of this.
s0044: Now I have again given a wife to Daluo, who bore the legitimate son Cheng.
s0045: With the intermarriage of Shen and Luo, all the Western Rong submit; this is why you are king.
s0047: King Xiao then said: 'Formerly, Boyi was Shun's master of livestock, and the livestock multiplied greatly, so he received land and was granted the surname Ying.
s0048: Now his descendants also raise horses for me, so I shall grant them territory as a dependent state.'
s0049: He established them at Qin, allowing them to continue the sacrifices of the Ying clan, and called them Qin Ying.
s0050: He also did not abolish the son of the Marquis of Shen's daughter as Luo's legitimate heir, in order to maintain peace with the Western Rong.
s0051: Qin Ying fathered Duke of Qin.
s0052: The Duke of Qin reigned for ten years and died.
s0054: Gongbo reigned for three years and died.
s0056: In the third year of Qin Zhong's reign, King Li of Zhou was tyrannical, and some feudal lords rebelled against him.
s0057: The Western Rong rebelled against the royal house and exterminated the Daluo clan at Quanqiu.
s0058: When King Xuan of Zhou ascended the throne, he made Qin Zhong a grand master and ordered him to punish the Western Rong.
s0059: The Western Rong killed Qin Zhong.
s0060: Qin Zhong had reigned for twenty-three years when he died at the hands of the Rong.
s0061: He had five sons, the eldest of whom was Duke Zhuang.
s0062: King Xuan of Zhou summoned Duke Zhuang and his four brothers, gave them seven thousand soldiers, and ordered them to attack the Western Rong. They defeated them.
s0063: Thereupon, he restored to Qin Zhong's descendants the lands of their ancestor Daluo at Quanqiu, and made them Grand Masters of the Western Frontier.
s0064: Duke Zhuang resided at the former Western Quanqiu and had three sons, the eldest being Shifu.
s0065: Shifu said: 'The Rong killed my grandfather Zhong. Unless I kill the Rong king, I will not dare enter the town.'
s0066: He then went to attack the Rong, yielding the succession to his younger brother Duke Xiang.
s0068: Duke Zhuang reigned for forty-four years and died. His heir, Duke Xiang, succeeded him.
s0069: In the first year of Duke Xiang's reign, he gave his younger sister Mu Ying in marriage to the king of Feng.
s0070: In the second year of Duke Xiang's reign, the Rong besieged Quanqiu. Shifu attacked them but was captured by the Rong.
s0071: After more than a year, Shifu was returned.
s0072: In the seventh year, in spring, King You of Zhou used Baosi to depose the heir apparent and made Baosi's son the legitimate heir. He repeatedly deceived the feudal lords, and the feudal lords rebelled against him.
s0073: The Western Rong and the Quanrong, together with the Marquis of Shen, attacked Zhou and killed King You below Mount Li.
s0074: Duke Xiang of Qin led troops to rescue Zhou, fought valiantly, and achieved merit.
s0075: Zhou fled from the Quanrong threat and moved east to Luoyi. Duke Xiang escorted King Ping of Zhou with his troops.
s0076: King Ping enfeoffed Duke Xiang as a feudal lord and granted him the lands west of Qi.
s0077: He said: 'The Rong are lawless and have invaded and seized our lands of Qi and Feng. If Qin can attack and drive out the Rong, the land shall be yours.'
s0078: He made a covenant with him and enfeoffed him with noble rank.
s0079: Thus Duke Xiang first established a state. He exchanged diplomatic courtesies with the other feudal lords, and offered sacrifices to the Supreme Deity at the Western Altar using three each of bay colts, yellow oxen, and rams.
s0080: In the twelfth year, he attacked the Rong and reached Qi, where he died.
s0082: In the first year of Duke Wen's reign, he resided at the Western Frontier Palace.
s0083: In the third year, Duke Wen led seven hundred soldiers on an eastern hunting expedition.
s0084: In the fourth year, he reached the confluence of the Qian and Wei rivers.
s0085: He said: 'Formerly, Zhou established our ancestor Qin Ying here, and eventually he became a feudal lord.'
s0086: He then divined about settling there, and the omen was auspicious, so he built a town there.
s0087: In the tenth year, he first established the Fu Altar and offered three sets of sacrificial animals.
s0088: In the thirteenth year, scribes were first employed to record events, and many people became civilized.
s0089: In the sixteenth year, Duke Wen led troops to attack the Rong, and the Rong were defeated and fled.
s0090: Duke Wen then gathered the remaining people of Zhou and possessed them, extending his territory to Qi. The lands east of Qi he offered to Zhou.
s0091: In the nineteenth year, he obtained the Chen Treasure.
s0092: In the twentieth year, laws first included punishment extending to three generations of kin.
s0093: In the twenty-seventh year, he cut down the great catalpa on the Southern Mountain, and encountered a great bull.
s0094: In the forty-eighth year, Duke Wen's heir apparent died and was posthumously titled Duke Jing.
s0095: Duke Jing's eldest son became heir apparent; he was Duke Wen's grandson.
s0096: In the fiftieth year, Duke Wen died and was buried at the Western Mountain.
s0097: Duke Jing's son ascended the throne; this was Duke Ning.
s0098: In the second year of Duke Ning's reign, the duke moved his residence to Pingyang.
s0099: He sent troops to attack Dangshe.
s0100: In the third year, he fought with Bo. The king of Bo fled to the Rong, and Dangshe was subsequently destroyed.
s0101: In the fourth year, the Lu prince Hui assassinated his ruler Duke Yin.
s0102: In the twelfth year, he attacked the Dang clan and captured them.
s0103: Duke Ning was ten years old when he ascended the throne, and reigned for twelve years before dying. He was buried at the Western Mountain.
s0104: He had three sons; the eldest, Duke Wu, was heir apparent.
s0105: Duke Wu's younger brother was Duke De, born of the same mother, the daughter of Lu Ji.
s0107: When Duke Ning died, the Grand Secretary Fuji, Weilei, and Sanfu deposed the heir apparent and established Chuzi as ruler.
s0108: In the sixth year of Chuzi's reign, Sanfu and the others again conspired to have someone assassinate Chuzi.
s0109: Chuzi was five years old when he was established, and ruled for six years before dying.
s0110: Sanfu and the others then reinstated the former heir apparent, Duke Wu.
s0111: In the first year of Duke Wu's reign, he attacked the Pengxi clan, reaching the foot of Mount Hua, and resided at the Feng Palace in Pingyang.
s0112: In the third year, he executed Sanfu and the others and exterminated their three clans, because they had killed Chuzi.
s0113: Gao Qumi of Zheng killed his ruler Duke Zhao.
s0114: In the tenth year, he attacked the Gui and Ji Rong, and first established them as counties.
s0115: In the eleventh year, he first established Du and Zheng as counties.
s0117: In the thirteenth year, Guan Zhifu and Lian Cheng of Qi killed their ruler Duke Xiang and established Gongsun Wuzhi.
s0118: Jin destroyed Huo, Wei, and Geng.
s0119: Yong Lin of Qi killed Wuzhi and Guan Zhifu and others, and established Duke Huan of Qi.
s0120: Qi and Jin became powerful states.
s0121: In the nineteenth year, Quwo of Jin first became the Marquis of Jin.
s0122: Duke Huan of Qi became hegemon at Juan.
s0123: In the twentieth year, Duke Wu died and was buried at Yong Pingyang.
s0124: For the first time, human sacrifices accompanied the burial; sixty-six people were sacrificed.
s0125: He had one son named Bai. Bai was not established as ruler, but was enfeoffed at Pingyang.
s0126: His younger brother Duke De was established.
s0127: In the first year of Duke De's reign, he first resided at the Dazheng Palace in the city of Yong.
s0128: He offered three hundred sets of sacrificial animals at the Fu Altar.
s0129: He divined about residing at Yong.
s0130: His descendants would water their horses at the Yellow River.
s0131: The Earl of Liang and the Earl of Rui came to pay court.
s0132: In the second year, the first Dog Days sacrifice was instituted, using dogs to ward off pestilence.
s0133: Duke De was thirty-three years old when he ascended the throne, and reigned for two years before dying.
s0134: He had three sons: the eldest was Duke Xuan, the second was Duke Cheng, and the youngest was Duke Mu.
s0135: The eldest son Duke Xuan was established.
s0136: In the first year of Duke Xuan's reign, Wei and Yan attacked Zhou, expelled King Hui, and established Prince Tui.
s0137: In the third year, the Earl of Zheng and Uncle of Guo killed Prince Tui and restored King Hui.
s0138: In the fourth year, he established the Mi Altar.
s0139: He fought with Jin at Heyang and defeated them.
s0140: In the twelfth year, Duke Xuan died.
s0141: He had nine sons, but none was established; his younger brother Duke Cheng was established.
s0142: In the first year of Duke Cheng's reign, the Earl of Liang and the Earl of Rui came to pay court.
s0143: Duke Huan of Qi attacked the Shanrong and encamped at Guzhu.
s0144: Duke Cheng reigned for four years and died.
s0145: He had seven sons, but none was established; his younger brother Duke Mu was established.
s0146: In the first year of Duke Mu Renhao's reign, he personally led an attack on Maojin and defeated it.
s0147: In the fourth year, he received a bride from Jin, who was the elder sister of Jin's heir apparent Shensheng.
s0148: That year, Duke Huan of Qi attacked Chu and reached Shaoling.
s0149: In the fifth year, Duke Xian of Jin destroyed Yu and Guo, and captured the ruler of Yu along with his minister Baili Xi, because they had bribed Yu with jade and horses.
s0150: After capturing Baili Xi, he was sent to Qin as an attendant for Duke Mu's wife.
s0151: Baili Xi fled from Qin to Wan, where he was seized by a man from the Chu border region.
s0152: Duke Mu heard that Baili Xi was worthy and wanted to ransom him at a high price, but feared Chu would not release him. So he sent someone to say to Chu: 'My attendant Baili Xi is there; please let me ransom him for five ram skins.'
s0154: The people of Chu agreed to give him up.
s0155: At that time, Baili Xi was already over seventy years old.
s0156: Duke Mu released him from captivity and discussed state affairs with him.
s0157: Baili Xi declined, saying: 'I am a minister of a fallen state; what is there to ask me?'
s0158: Duke Mu said: 'The ruler of Yu did not employ you, and so perished. It was not your fault.'
s0159: He persisted in questioning him, and they talked for three days. Duke Mu was greatly pleased, entrusted him with the administration of the state, and called him 'Grand Master of the Five Ram Skins.'
s0160: Baili Xi declined, saying: 'I am not as good as my friend Jian Shu. Jian Shu is worthy, but the world does not know him.
s0161: I once wandered in poverty in Qi and begged for food in Zhi. Jian Shu took me in.
s0162: Because of this, I wanted to serve the ruler of Qi, Wuzhi, but Jian Shu stopped me, and I escaped the troubles in Qi and went to Zhou.
s0163: The Zhou prince Tui loved cattle, and I approached him through raising cattle.
s0164: When Tui was about to employ me, Jian Shu stopped me; I left and avoided being executed.
s0165: When I served the ruler of Yu, Jian Shu stopped me.
s0166: I knew the ruler of Yu would not employ me, but I was truly covetous of the salary and rank, so I stayed.
s0167: Twice I followed his advice and escaped; once I did not follow it, and I was caught up in Yu's troubles. This is how I know he is worthy.'
s0168: Duke Mu then sent someone with generous gifts to invite Jian Shu, and made him a Senior Grand Master.
s0169: In the autumn, Duke Mu personally led an attack on Jin and fought at Hequ.
s0170: Li Ji of Jin caused turmoil. The heir apparent Shensheng died at Xincheng, and Chong'er and Yiwu fled.
s0171: In the ninth year, Duke Huan of Qi held a meeting of the feudal lords at Kuiqiu.
s0173: Li Ji's son Xiqi was established, but the minister Li Ke killed Xiqi.
s0174: Xun Xi established Zhuozi, but Li Ke again killed Zhuozi and Xun Xi.
s0175: Yiwu sent someone to request Qin's help to enter Jin.
s0176: Duke Mu agreed and sent Baili Xi to lead troops escorting Yiwu.
s0177: Yiwu said: 'If I am truly established, I will cede eight cities west of the Jin river to Qin.'
s0178: When he arrived and was established, he sent Pi Zheng to apologize to Qin, reneged on the agreement and did not give the cities west of the river, and killed Li Ke.
s0179: When Pi Zheng heard this, he was afraid, and so conspired with Duke Mu, saying: 'The people of Jin do not want Yiwu; they really want Chong'er.
s0180: Now that he has broken the agreement with Qin and killed Li Ke, this is all the plan of Lü Sheng and Xi Rui.
s0181: I hope you will urgently summon Lü and Xi with promises of gain; when they come, it will be convenient to install Chong'er instead.'
s0182: Duke Mu agreed, and sent someone with Pi Zheng to return and summon Lü and Xi.
s0183: Lü, Xi, and the others suspected that Pi Zheng was plotting against them, so they told Yiwu to kill Pi Zheng.
s0184: Pi Zheng's son Pi Bao fled to Qin and persuaded Duke Mu, saying: 'The ruler of Jin is unprincipled and the people are not attached to him; he can be attacked.'
s0185: Duke Mu said: 'If the people are truly dissatisfied, how was he able to execute his minister?
s0186: That he could execute his minister shows he has control.'
s0187: He did not listen, but secretly employed Pi Bao.
s0188: In the twelfth year, Guan Zhong and Xi Peng of Qi died.
s0189: Jin had a drought and came to request grain.
s0190: Pi Bao urged Duke Mu not to give it, but to attack them while they were starving.
s0191: Duke Mu asked Gongsun Zhi, who said: 'Famine and plenty alternate; we cannot refuse.'
s0192: He asked Baili Xi, who said: 'Yiwu offended you, but what crime did his people commit?'
s0193: So following the advice of Baili Xi and Gongsun Zhi, he gave them grain.
s0194: By boat and cart transport, an unbroken line stretched from Yong to Jiang.
s0195: In the fourteenth year, Qin had a famine and requested grain from Jin.
s0196: The ruler of Jin consulted his ministers.
s0197: Guo She said: 'Attack them while they are starving, and you can achieve great merit.'
s0198: The ruler of Jin followed this advice.
s0199: In the fifteenth year, he raised troops to attack Qin.
s0200: Duke Mu mobilized his forces, sent Pi Bao as general, and went himself to attack them.
s0201: On the renxu day of the ninth month, he joined battle with Duke Hui of Jin, Yiwu, at Han.
s0202: The ruler of Jin abandoned his army and competed with Qin for advantage; as he turned back, his horse stumbled.
s0203: Duke Mu and his bodyguards rode in pursuit, but could not catch the ruler of Jin, and were instead surrounded by the Jin army.
s0204: Jin attacked Duke Mu, and Duke Mu was wounded.
s0205: At that moment, three hundred men from below Mount Qi who had eaten his good horses charged through the Jin army. The Jin army broke their encirclement, and they rescued Duke Mu and in turn captured the ruler of Jin alive.
s0206: Earlier, Duke Mu had lost some fine horses, and more than three hundred commoners below Mount Qi had caught and eaten them together. Officials tracked them down and wanted to punish them according to law.
s0207: Duke Mu said: 'A gentleman does not harm people for the sake of livestock.
s0208: I have heard that eating good horse meat without drinking wine harms a person.'
s0209: So he gave them all wine and pardoned them.
s0210: When the three hundred men heard that Qin was attacking Jin, they all sought to join the campaign. When they saw Duke Mu in distress, they all charged forward and vied to die for him, to repay his kindness in the matter of the horses.
s0211: Duke Mu then brought the captured ruler of Jin home and issued an order throughout the state that they should purify themselves, for he would sacrifice the ruler of Jin to the Supreme Deity.
s0212: When the Zhou Son of Heaven heard this, he said, 'Jin is of the same surname as us,' and requested the release of the ruler of Jin.
s0213: Yiwu's elder sister was also Duke Mu's wife. When she heard this, she put on mourning clothes, went barefoot, and said: 'My brother and I cannot save each other, and thus we have disgraced your command.'
s0214: Duke Mu said: 'I captured the ruler of Jin as an achievement, but now the Son of Heaven requests his release, and my wife is distressed.'
s0215: So he made a covenant with the ruler of Jin, agreed to return him, moved him to better quarters, and presented him with seven sets of sacrificial animals.
s0216: In the eleventh month, he returned the ruler of Jin, Yiwu. Yiwu ceded his lands west of the river and sent his heir apparent Yu as a hostage to Qin.
s0217: Qin gave a woman of the royal clan in marriage to Yu.
s0218: At this time, Qin's territory extended east to the Yellow River.
s0219: In the eighteenth year, Duke Huan of Qi died.
s0220: In the twentieth year, Qin destroyed Liang and Rui.
s0221: In the twenty-second year, Prince Yu of Jin heard that the ruler of Jin was ill, and said: 'Liang is my mother's home, and Qin has destroyed it.
s0222: I have many brothers. When the ruler passes, Qin will certainly detain me, and Jin will regard me lightly and establish another son.'
s0223: So Yu fled and returned to Jin.
s0224: In the twenty-third year, Duke Hui of Jin died, and Yu was established as ruler.
s0225: Qin resented Yu for fleeing, so they welcomed Prince Chong'er of Jin from Chu and gave him Yu's former wife in marriage.
s0226: Chong'er at first declined, but later accepted.
s0227: Duke Mu treated him with ever greater courtesy and generosity.
s0228: In the spring of the twenty-fourth year, Qin sent someone to tell the ministers of Jin that they wished to install Chong'er.
s0229: Jin agreed, and so they sent someone to escort Chong'er.
s0230: In the second month, Chong'er was established as ruler of Jin; this was Duke Wen.
s0231: Duke Wen had someone kill Yu.
s0232: Yu was known as Duke Huai.
s0233: That autumn, King Xiang of Zhou's younger brother Dai attacked the king with the Di, and the king went to live in Zheng.
s0234: In the twenty-fifth year, the Zhou king sent someone to report the troubles to Jin and Qin.
s0235: Duke Mu of Qin led troops to help Duke Wen of Jin restore King Xiang and killed the king's brother Dai.
s0236: In the twenty-eighth year, Duke Wen of Jin defeated Chu at Chengpu.
s0237: In the thirtieth year, Duke Mu assisted Duke Wen of Jin in besieging Zheng.
s0238: Zheng sent someone to say to Duke Mu: 'Destroying Zheng will benefit Jin; Jin will gain from it, but Qin will have no benefit.
s0240: Duke Mu then withdrew his troops and returned.
s0242: In the winter of the thirty-second year, Duke Wen of Jin died.
s0243: A man from Zheng came to sell out Zheng to Qin, saying: 'I am in charge of the city gates; Zheng can be taken by surprise.'
s0244: Duke Mu asked Jian Shu and Baili Xi, who replied: 'To travel a thousand li through several states to attack someone by surprise rarely succeeds.
s0245: Moreover, if someone is selling out Zheng, how do we know that someone from our own state will not inform Zheng of our plans?
s0247: Duke Mu said: 'You do not understand; I have already decided.'
s0248: So he dispatched troops, sending Baili Xi's son Mengming Shi, Jian Shu's son Xi Qishu, and Bai Yibing to lead the army.
s0249: On the day they departed, Baili Xi and Jian Shu wept for them.
s0250: Duke Mu heard of this and angrily said: 'I dispatch troops and you weep to demoralize my army; why?'
s0251: The two elders said: 'We would not dare to demoralize your army.
s0252: The army marches, and our sons go with it;
s0253: we are old, and fear we will not live to see their return, so we weep.'
s0254: The two elders withdrew and said to their sons: 'When your army is defeated, it will certainly be at the Xiao Pass.'
s0255: In the spring of the thirty-third year, the Qin army marched east, crossed Jin territory, and passed by the north gate of Zhou.
s0256: Prince Man of Zhou said: 'The Qin army is disrespectful; what else can they expect but defeat!'
s0257: When the army reached Hua, a Zheng merchant named Xian Gao, who was taking twelve oxen to sell in Zhou, saw the Qin army. Fearing he would be killed or captured, he presented his oxen, saying: 'I have heard that a great power is coming to punish Zheng. The ruler of Zheng is carefully preparing his defenses, and has sent me with twelve oxen to reward the soldiers.'
s0258: The three Qin generals said to each other: 'We were going to surprise Zheng, but now Zheng is aware of it; there is no point in going.'
s0260: Hua was a border town of Jin.
s0261: At that time, Duke Wen of Jin's coffin had not yet been buried.
s0262: The heir apparent Duke Xiang angrily said: 'Qin has insulted me as an orphan, taking advantage of the mourning period to destroy our Hua.'
s0263: So he dyed his mourning clothes black, dispatched troops to intercept the Qin army at Xiao, and attacked them, completely destroying the Qin army. Not one man escaped.
s0264: He captured the three Qin generals and brought them back.
s0265: Duke Wen's wife was a Qin woman. On behalf of the three imprisoned Qin generals, she requested: 'Duke Mu's hatred of these three men has entered his very bones and marrow. I beg you to let these three men return, so that my lord may have the pleasure of boiling them himself.'
s0266: The ruler of Jin agreed and returned the three Qin generals.
s0267: When the three generals arrived, Duke Mu put on plain clothes, went out to the suburbs to meet them, and wept to the three men, saying: 'Because I did not follow the advice of Baili Xi and Jian Shu, I brought disgrace upon you three. What was your crime?
s0268: You must devote yourselves wholeheartedly to washing away this shame; do not be negligent.'
s0269: He then restored the three men to their former ranks and offices, and treated them even more generously.
s0270: In the thirty-fourth year, Prince Shangchen of Chu assassinated his father King Cheng and took his place.
s0271: Duke Mu then again sent Mengming Shi and the others to lead troops against Jin, and they fought at Pengya.
s0272: Qin did not prevail and withdrew its troops.
s0273: The king of the Rong sent You Yu to Qin.
s0274: You Yu's ancestors were people of Jin who had fled to the Rong, and he could speak the Jin language.
s0275: Hearing that Duke Mu was worthy, he sent You Yu to observe Qin.
s0276: Duke Mu of Qin showed him the palaces and storehouses.
s0277: You Yu said: 'If spirits made these, then the spirits have been wearied.
s0278: If men made these, then the people have been oppressed.'
s0279: Duke Mu was surprised and asked: 'The Central States use the Odes, Documents, rites, music, and laws to govern, yet they still have disorder from time to time. Now the Rong and Yi have none of these; how do they govern? Is it not difficult?'
s0280: You Yu laughed and said: 'This is precisely why the Central States are in disorder.
s0281: From the time when the sage Huangdi created rites, music, and laws, and practiced them himself, there was barely minor order.
s0282: By subsequent generations, they became daily more arrogant and dissolute.
s0283: They relied on the authority of laws to demand service from their subordinates. When the subordinates were exhausted, they resented the superiors on grounds of humanity and righteousness. Superiors and subordinates fought and resented each other, leading to usurpation and regicide until whole clans were exterminated. All such cases belong to this pattern.
s0284: The Rong and Yi are not like this.
s0285: Superiors embrace simple virtue in treating their subordinates; subordinates cherish loyalty and trust in serving their superiors. The government of the whole state is like the governance of one body. They do not know by what means they govern; this is truly the government of sages.'
s0286: Duke Mu withdrew and asked the Palace Scribe Liao: 'I have heard that when a neighboring state has a sage, it is a worry for rival states.
s0287: Now You Yu is worthy; he is a threat to me. What shall I do about it?'
s0288: Palace Scribe Liao said: 'The Rong king dwells in a remote place and has not heard the sounds of the Central States.
s0289: Try sending him female musicians to beguile his mind;
s0290: request You Yu for him, to create a rift between them;

s0607: In the thirtieth year, the Shu governor Ruo attacked Chu, captured the Wu Commandery, and made the area south of the river the Qianzhong Commandery.
s0608: In the thirty-first year, Bai Qi attacked Wei and captured two cities.
s0609: The Chu people took back our territory south of the river.
s0610: In the thirty-second year, Prime Minister Marquis Rang attacked Wei, reaching Daliang, defeated Bao Yuan, beheaded forty thousand, and Bao Yuan fled. Wei ceded three counties to sue for peace.
s0611: In the thirty-third year, the guest minister Hu Yang attacked Wei's Juan, Caiyang, and Changshe, and captured them.
s0612: He struck Mang Mao at Huayang and defeated him, beheading one hundred fifty thousand.
s0613: Wei ceded Nanyang to make peace.
s0614: In the thirty-fourth year, Qin, Wei, and Han combined the Shangyong territory into one commandery, and freed servants from Nanyang were relocated there.
s0615: In the thirty-fifth year, he assisted Han, Wei, and Chu in attacking Yan.
s0616: The Nanyang Commandery was first established.
s0617: In the thirty-sixth year, the guest minister Zao attacked Qi and captured Gang and Shou, which were given to Marquis Rang.
s0618: In the thirty-eighth year, Middle Senior Hu Yang attacked Zhao's Eyu but could not capture it.
s0619: In the fortieth year, the Mourning Heir Apparent died in Wei; his body was returned and buried at Zhiyang.
s0620: In the summer of the forty-first year, he attacked Wei and captured Xingqiu and Huai.
s0621: In the forty-second year, Lord Anguo was made heir apparent.
s0622: In the tenth month, Queen Dowager Xuan died and was buried at Zhiyang on Mount Li.
s0623: In the ninth month, Marquis Rang departed for Tao.
s0624: In the forty-third year, Lord of Wu'an Bai Qi attacked Han, captured nine cities, and beheaded fifty thousand.
s0625: In the forty-fourth year, he attacked Han's Nanyang and captured it.
s0626: In the forty-fifth year, the Fifth-Rank Minister Ben attacked Han and captured ten cities.
s0627: Lord Yeyang Hui departed for his state but died before arriving.
s0628: In the forty-seventh year, Qin attacked Han's Shangdang. Shangdang surrendered to Zhao, so Qin then attacked Zhao. Zhao dispatched troops to strike Qin, and they faced off against each other.
s0629: Qin sent Lord of Wu'an Bai Qi to attack, and he utterly defeated Zhao at Changping, killing all of more than four hundred thousand.
s0630: In the tenth month of the forty-eighth year, Han offered Yuanyong.
s0631: The Qin army was divided into three forces.
s0633: Wang He led an attack on Zhao's Pilao and captured it.
s0634: Sima Geng pacified Taiyuan in the north, and all of Han's Shangdang was annexed.
s0635: In the first month, the troops were dismissed and returned to defend Shangdang.
s0636: In the tenth month, Fifth-Rank Minister Ling attacked Zhao's Handan.
s0637: In the first month of the forty-ninth year, more troops were dispatched to assist Ling.
s0638: Ling fought poorly and was dismissed; Wang He took command.
s0639: In the tenth month, General Zhang Tang attacked Wei. Commander Cai Wei Juanfu did not defend, and upon returning, he was executed.
s0640: In the tenth month of the fiftieth year, Lord of Wu'an Bai Qi was found guilty, demoted to the rank of common soldier, and exiled to Yinmi.
s0641: Zhang Tang attacked Zheng and captured it.
s0642: In the twelfth month, more troops were dispatched to the army near Fencheng.
s0643: Lord of Wu'an Bai Qi was found guilty and executed.
s0644: Wang He attacked Handan but could not capture it; he withdrew and fled to join the army at Fen.
s0645: After two months of attacking the Jin army, he beheaded six thousand, and twenty thousand Jin and Chu soldiers drowned in the river.
s0646: He attacked Fencheng, then followed Tang to capture Ningxinzhong; Ningxinzhong was renamed Anyang.
s0647: The first river bridge was built.
s0648: In the fifty-first year, General Jiu attacked Han and captured Yangcheng and Fushu, beheading forty thousand.
s0649: He attacked Zhao and captured more than twenty counties, with ninety thousand killed or captured.
s0650: The Lord of Western Zhou turned against Qin and made an alliance with the feudal lords, intending to bring the best troops of all under heaven out of Yique to attack Qin, ordering that Qin should not be allowed to reach Yangcheng.
s0651: Thereupon Qin sent General Jiu to attack Western Zhou.
s0652: The Lord of Western Zhou came running to surrender, prostrating himself and confessing his crimes, offering all his thirty-six towns with thirty thousand inhabitants.
s0653: The King of Qin accepted the surrender and returned the lord to Zhou.
s0654: In the fifty-second year, the people of Zhou fled eastward, and the Nine Tripods entered Qin.
s0656: In the fifty-third year, all under heaven came to submit.
s0657: Wei was last; Qin sent Jiu to attack Wei and capture Wucheng.
s0658: The king of Han came to pay court; Wei entrusted its state and obeyed orders.
s0659: In the fifty-fourth year, the king made a suburban sacrifice to the Supreme Deity at Yong.
s0660: In the autumn of the fifty-sixth year, King Zhaoxiang died; his son King Xiaowen succeeded him.
s0661: He honored the Consort Tang Bazi as Queen Dowager Tang, and had her buried together with the former king.
s0662: The king of Han came in mourning clothes to offer condolences and sacrifices; all the feudal lords sent their generals and ministers to offer condolences and attend to the funeral.
s0663: In the first year of King Xiaowen, criminals were pardoned, the meritorious ministers of former kings were honored, relatives were treated generously, and the hunting parks were opened.
s0664: King Xiaowen ended his mourning period, was enthroned on the yihai day of the tenth month, and died three days later on the xinzhou day. His son King Zhuangxiang succeeded him.
s0665: In the first year of King Zhuangxiang, there was a great amnesty for criminals, meritorious ministers of former kings were honored, kindness was extended to relatives, and benevolence was spread to the people.
s0666: The Lord of Eastern Zhou conspired with the feudal lords against Qin. Qin sent Prime Minister Lü Buwei to execute him and annexed his entire state.
s0667: Qin did not end his sacrifices, but granted the Lord of Zhou the territory of Yangren to maintain his ancestral worship.
s0668: Meng Ao was sent to attack Han; Han ceded Chenggao and Gong.
s0669: Qin's border reached Daliang; the Sanchuan Commandery was first established.
s0670: In the second year, Meng Ao was sent to attack Zhao and pacified Taiyuan.
s0671: In the third year, Meng Ao attacked Wei's Gaodu and Ji and captured them.
s0672: He attacked Zhao's Yuci, Xincheng, and Langmeng, taking thirty-seven cities.
s0673: In the fourth month, there was a solar eclipse.
s0675: The Taiyuan Commandery was first established.
s0676: Wuji, general of Wei, led the troops of five states to attack Qin; Qin retreated beyond the river.
s0677: Meng Ao was defeated and withdrew.
s0678: On the bingwu day of the fifth month, King Zhuangxiang died; his son Zheng succeeded him. This was the First Emperor of Qin.
s0679: King Zheng of Qin ruled for twenty-six years, first unified all under heaven into thirty-six commanderies, and took the title First Emperor.
s0680: The First Emperor ruled for fifty-one years and died; his son Huhai succeeded him. This was the Second Emperor.
s0681: In the third year, the feudal lords all rose up in rebellion against Qin. Zhao Gao killed the Second Emperor and established Ziying.
s0682: Ziying had been established for just over a month when the feudal lords executed him, and Qin was thereupon destroyed.
s0683: This account is found in the Basic Annals of the First Emperor.
s0684: The Grand Historian says: The ancestors of Qin bore the surname Ying.
s0685: Their descendants were later enfeoffed and took their states as surnames, including the Xu clan, the Tan clan, the Ju clan, the Zhongli clan, the Yunyan clan, the Tuqiu clan, the Jiangliang clan, the Huang clan, the Jiang clan, the Xiuyu clan, the Baiming clan, the Feilian clan, and the Qin clan.
s0686: However, Qin took the surname Zhao because their ancestor Zaofu was enfeoffed with the city of Zhao.
